content.text:
# Citizen Science, the Body of Christ, and Testimonial Epistemology - Toward a Distributed Theology

_by Benedikt Friedrich, Hanna Reichel, Thomas Renkert_

---	

## Abstract
> _How_ does explicit theological knowledge emerge out of communal practices, _who_ is involved in its production, and _what_ are its procedures? These are neither neutral nor arbitrary methodological questions, they are themselves deeply theological. Digital innovations and the subsequent transformations of society and academia invite us to redefine the work of theology. Epistemologically drawing on a theology of the cross and centering the communal nature and vulnerable existence of the witnessing community, we develop a model of doing theology that is collaborative and exploratory within the medial transformations of the digital age. Taking cues from participatory research conceptions of Citizen Science, we propose going toward and beyond a Citizen Theology. We need the courage to conceive of a theology that is ultimately centerless. Therefore, we cannot aspire to testimonially responsible forms of doing theology without striving for epistemic justice and diaconal empowerment at a global level. The Distributed Theology we envision promotes global (catholic), decentral (apostolic), and communal (local) forms of knowledge production by the whole of the body of Christ in ever more distributed ways.

---	

## Using scuttlebutt as a medium for academic debate

Disclaimer: This is an experiment in distributed publishing. The paper itself is hosted via #Dat while comments on the paper are hosted on #ssb.

---

content.text:
This is an interesting article on *moral* *games* where a small group of friends came up with rules to modify their own behaviour to live more sustainable lives. They use a point system for mostly positive and some negative reinforcement: https://www.zeit.de/die-antwort/2019-11/nachhaltigkeit-umweltschutz-alltag-moral-games

(Article is in German, but you can read it in other languages using deepl.com)

Anyway, I thought that this would be an interesting use case for a #patchapp: A client for small groups (and maybe larger groups as well, like teams competing for "moral superiority") to develop rules and point systems, to record their progress and hold each other accountable. Something that could have milestones and rewards, similar to habitica.com.



#climatechange  #games #gamification #ethics #sustainability #solidarity #accountability

friends.name: Linas
friends.description:
I am unable to describe myself.

OK. But I can try.  I am interested in meaning. For example, what do these words mean? What does this sentence mean? What does it mean for me to say this? What does it mean when you read this? Were you searching for meaning, when you read this? Of course you were. That's what humans do.

One reason I'm interested in #meaning is because I am trying to make machines (robots, computers) that also search for and find meaning. (some people call this #agi) I want to understand the theory of meaning. For me, that means knowing a lot of #mathematics. (I really do know a LOT of rather advanced mathematics.)

But there's something else: the modern crisis of meaning. #fake-news, what does it mean? #sense-making, what does it mean? #meme ? #propaganda ? #conspiracy theory? #socialjustice ? #alt-right ? #antifa ? #pansexual #lgbtq ? #capitalism ? #economics ? What does it mean? Why do people say and do these things? These are social phenomena: its #sociology in the broad.  This is society, trying to find meaning within itself.  Waves of unfettered thinking washing over our neurons.

So .. that's some of what is .. interesting to me .. there's more. But .. enough about me. (Come be my friend, if you too are interested in such things).

friends.name: umhi
friends.description:
![hisforhome.jpg](&l6SIpED5yoUtohZW7SiCXOn7qgfYOdFuTYZNQdPoUUc=.sha256)

Hi everyone, my name is Seán. I'm a non-dev human living in Victoria, BC, Canada, Earth, Laniākea with my partner [@Wingy Scruffhead](@weUmuMeI+unghjmNOMnuhihpC1rdyDcAKTpnoMjuunc=.ed25519) - a fellow non-dev (only part-hummingbird) who's learning to use ssb with me (and painted the muppet-me that I'm currently using as an avatar). After years of disillusionment with the web, I'm slowly reconnecting with the online realm by exploring tools / platforms which seek to foster learning, sharing, creativity, and human autonomy - in contrast to the automated mega-malls that surveil, insulate, manipulate, and infantilize people for profit... which led me to Scuttlebutt!

I initially ended up here because I stumbled across [@The Local Gossip](@URIdonHSF4eAIZVqPPe6I+lkDd19Bl0T/t4/umwtbo4=.ed25519), [@Zach!](@ZqH7Mctu/7DNInxuwl12ECjfrAKUX2tBLq1rOldNhg0=.ed25519), and [@Angelica](@eANNuLfzX/9rlGODXHYV8WJb+zw2h+d7YsT4vpYPvD0=.ed25519) while exploring Beaker - whose words resonated with so many of my own feelings about the state of 'cyber-meatspace' and healthier ways forward. After lurking on & off for a bit here, I've become increasingly enamored with this tool / space / community because it elicits an excitement in me about the digital realm which has largely lain dormant since the web of the late 90s that I grew up exploring--a sense of adventure, experimentation, collaborative learning, fun, and actually-human-feeling long-distance-connection. Above all, it feels like a warm, non-coercive invitation to become an active digital citizen again without sacrificing my humanity/wellbeing/autonomy - a feeling very much unlike the cold, manipulative demands *to submit* that I've experienced in 'Web 2.0'-oriented spaces.

As for my broader biography, I was born in the dry, hot desert of the southwestern United States during the ancient era when people's souls were bound to the earth & the sky rather than stuck in #the-cloud. Then I lived in the wet, lushly-forested Seattle area for two decades as the 'Emerald City' became the Amazon Jungle™. Now I live in self-imposed exile on a rocky outcrop at the edge of an island in southwestern Canada where I've been cultivating new roots, composting old ones, and trying to gradually untangle my self from the strangling tendrils of 'Web 2.0' and 'Big Tech', while also helping my friends/family/community do so as well along the way.

Other than that, I've always struggled to describe my self-conception in a neat, satisfactory way, and prefer to remain fairly ambiguous (p.s. I don't believe in a static 'self')... I suppose you could say that I'm a wandering generalist of sorts with no particular specialization and a malleable range of interests. But for practical social / 'networking' purposes, I'll add that over the past year, I've been focusing much of my attention on issues relating to human autonomy, selfhood & identity, family heritage, death literacy, community broadening, and face-to-face connection across social divides.

Activity-wise, I try to spend the majority of my time offline doing archaic World 1.0 things like walking around without a phone, reading books, making food & art (& food art) with my partner, spending time with my family, and making friendly eye contact / striking up conversations with unknown humans in public spaces. Oh, and noticing birds and other creatures that live on this planet who don't care about the Internet. On the other hand, I'm also deeply invested in a few digital projects which I may share more about here later...

I should emphasize that I'm not so much interested in meeting people 'like me' - who will nod along with everything I say - as I am in meeting people *seemingly unlike me* - who I can nonetheless potentially relate to, disagree with respectfully, & learn from, and with whom I can build some sense of trust & meaningful connection. I'm also a slow, introverted person at heart with a limited capacity for social engagement, both off- and online, who withers without a significant amount of untethered alone time. Sometimes I drop down to absolute minimum Internet usage for extended periods of time in order to take care of my other priorities and needs.

On that note, this is getting rather long and I've reached my capacity to be 'plugged in' for today, so I'll leave it there and probably add an extended version of this to my profile at some point. My activity here will likely be fairly intermittent - at least for the next month or so - but I hope to become more regularly active after I attend to some other imminent life priorities.

Thanks for taking the time to read my ramble - I look forward to learning more about other wayfaring scuttlebutts in time, developing my understanding of how this place functions, and hopefully helping to create more well-trodden pathways to the world beyond :^)

Sincerely,
Seán [♪](https://dianecluck.info/track/2242964/original-face)

>ø\‣

requestsSent.name: andrestaltz
requestsSent.description:
Creator of Manyverse
Website http://staltz.com
Same person as [andrestaltz_phone](@+UMKhpbzXAII+2/7ZlsgkJwIsxdfeFi36Z5Rk1gCfY0=.ed25519
)

Cultural background:
I'm multicultural (not multiethnical), because I was born in Brazil but lived in the USA during 4 of the key years of my childhood, and am now living in Finland for the last 9 years. I don't fully identify myself with any of those three countries/cultures, but they seem to balance each other in influencing my background. It is quite inaccurate to call me Brazilian, as well as it's inaccurate to call me Finnish. This used to be a matter of shame/discomfort for me in the past, nowadays I appreciate this fuzzy cultural alignment.

Communication style: 
Probably a blend of those cultures. I mean only what I say (I don't communicate by implying or suggesting), I speak directly which can be misunderstood as an intent to be rude, but honestly it's more about simplicity of thought and straightforward messages. I like to think about problems and challenges and uncomfortable truths, these actually motivate me to either solve them if they are solvable, or to study them and learn something philosophical if they are unsolvable. I try to be sensitive with this tendency though, because problems and challenges and uncomfortable truths can be demotivating to others. It's safe to assume I have a friendly tone while I'm direct, and if there's miscommunication/misunderstaning I'll try to apologize. 

Political background:
I'm left-leaning but not to a specific ideology, I just believe that a society worth living in is egalitarian (egalitarian upon people's worth, not upon their function in society), inclusive, non-competitive, fair, balanced, symbiotic (everyone and everything is vital to the whole). I don't have a black-and-white alignment, and can reasonably talk about the positive (isolated?) effects of capitalism, but in the end of the day I can't psychologically align myself with meritocracy, superiority, zero-sum competition, centralization/assimilation, hegemonies, accumulation of power, individualism, and the likes.

RPG alignment: Neutral Good

Business background:
In the past I have had a startup, nowadays I do consulting and training as a self-employed person. You could say I have the mind of product designer and CEO. This and other aspects of Manyverse has often led people to believe that Manyverse will at some point become a business. That's not going to happen, I'm personally fond of a donation-driven style of project development.

Blocking style:
I will block accounts that post content NSFW, accounts that intentionally disrespect others, and occassionally "random" accounts (or just unrelated to me) that I am not sure I want to host on my local SSB database.

requestsSent.name: Viktor Zaunders
requestsSent.description:
I am starting to think that **bridging** is my basic function.

Much of what I do can be seen as *connective tissue design*. I work a lot with fungi, soil and water. My passion for and identification with fungi also highly influences [my thinking](https://medium.com/@zaunders/can-fungal-like-tech-help-us-grow-from-competitors-to-collaborators-d3526a2396a) around organisation and technology. 

I work with:

* Land management & Soil flourishing
* Enterprise Design
* Organisational Tools
* Fungal Experiments
* Learning

I see my overarching efforts going towards connecting ideas, people, technology and biota. 

So you see, I am happy to connect :wink:

requestsSent.name: Marlon
requestsSent.description:
Here are things i'd love to talk with you about:

# technologist
interested in ops, infosec, and infrastructure automation for social movements. Co-founder of worker-owned tech cooperative [Bramble](https://bramble.coop). Interested/experienced in:
- Secure digital collaboration tools
- Network autonomy, secure hosting
- Off-grid wireless communication (LoRa, WiFi, Ham, etc)
- Security training for activists


# anarchist
Activist with a focus on grassroots conflictual organizing. Member of the [Teardown Community](https://theteardown.org), an intentional community in #Atlanta GA USA which builds infrastructure for popular struggle. Lots of experience with stuff like:
- Copwatch
- Food Not Bombs
- Indymedia
- Prison abolition
- Protest mobilizations
- Facilitation and group process
